My name is Alex Flint from Oxford University and this is joint work with Chrisney Ian Reed and David Murray.

So as you know, modern slam systems are able to accurately reconstruct point clouds from video sequences, but these point clouds are not always easy to interpret for high level scene understanding purposes.
Our work here tries to take a video sequence and produced not just a point cloud, put a semantically meaningful model such as that shown on the right over here.
So our motivation here is twofold.

First, we want to be able to answer high level questions such as is this a kitchen or a corridor, or where in this scene would be most likely to find a window now just to outline three outcomes from our approach.
Firstly, our approach is able to reconstruct in real time models that include semantically meaningful labels such as floor, wall and ceiling.
Secondly, you'll notice that a lot of the information from the original video sequences actually lost in the projection to a 3D point cloud representation.
Our approach builds on recent work in Single View reconstruction to include cues from the photometric information, not just the geometric information.

And finally, our approach combines information across multiple frames so that we're able to reconstruct difficult frames such as those shown in the bottom row, which would be difficult to interpret as isolated images.
Thank you very much.
